relation: switch# test aaa server radius {ipv4-address| ipv6-address | server-name} [vrf vrf-name] username password test aaa server radius {ipv4-address | ipv6-address | server-name} [vrf vrf-name] username password
switch# test aaa group group-name username password
Sends a test message to a RADIUS server to confirm availability.
Sends a test message to a RADIUS server group to confirm availability.
pageTitle: Cisco Nexus 6000 Series NX-OS Security Configuration Guide, Release 6.x - Configuring RADIUS [Cisco Nexus 6000 Series Switches] - Cisco
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {31490=Configures the monitoring dead time. The default is 0 minutes. The range is from 1 through 1440., 66804=The valid range is 1 to 1440 minutes., 71760=Configures the dead-time interval. The default value is 0 minutes. The range is from 1 to 1440 minutes., 65796=The valid range is from 0 to 1440 minutes., 58907=Specifies a UDP port to use for RADIUS authentication messages. The default UDP port is 1812., 57408=Specifies a UDP port to use for RADIUS accounting messages. The default UDP port is 1812.}
textBeforeTable: Procedure You must configure the IPv4 or IPv6 address or the hostname for each RADIUS server that you want to use for authentication. All RADIUS server hosts are added to the default RADIUS server group. You can configure up to 64 RADIUS servers. Configuring RADIUS Server Hosts If needed, configure periodic RADIUS server monitoring. Step 5   Accounting and authentication attributes. Transmission retry count and timeout interval. Allow specification of a RADIUS server at login. Dead-time interval. If needed, configure any of the following optional parameters: Step 4   If needed, configure RADIUS server groups with subsets of the RADIUS servers for AAA authentication methods. Step 3   Configure the preshared secret keys for the RADIUS servers. Step 2   Establish the RADIUS server connections to the Cisco Nexus device. Step 1
textAfterTable: Step 3 switch(config)# exit   Exits configuration mode.   Step 4 switch# show radius-server   (Optional) Displays the RADIUS server configuration.   Step 5 switch# copy running-config startup-config   (Optional) Saves the change persistently through reboots and restarts by copying the running configuration to the startup configuration.   The following example shows how to configure host 10.10.1.1 as a RADIUS server:  switch# configure terminal switch(config)# radius-server host 10.10.1.1 switch(config)# exit switch# copy running-config startup-config Configuring RADIUS Global Preshared Keys You can configure preshared keys at the global level for all servers used by the Cisco Nexus device. A preshared key is a shared secret text string between the switch and the RADIUS server hosts. Before You Begin Obtain the preshared key values for the remote RADIUS servers Procedure   Command or Action Purpose Step 1 switch#
